field.name: compress_css
field.label: Compress CSS
field.description: Compresses the script(s)) of the document in order to speed up the loading process

field.name: compress_inline_css
field.label: Compress inline-CSS
field.description: Compresses inline-script (header only) as well? IMPORTANT : Do NOT use this, if your header-scripts contain any parts, that change with every call of the page ( for example timestamps or random ID's or anything alike ), since that would casue the plugin to create a new cachefile with every call of the page and you will not want this, since it a) slows down the loading of the page in comparison to calling a readily processed and cached file. Probably still faster for the browser to load than many uncompressed files, BUT b) it will spam your cache-folder. In such case you better set this option to NO !

field.name: compress_css_cache_gzipped
field.label: create GZIPped cachefile ?
field.description: If set to YES, then the caches file will not be a pure text based script file, but contain some PHP at the beginning that does some gzipping stuff before it spits out the cached and minified content, this minifying the content even further. If you have an EXTREMELY lot of visitors per time on your site, u might consider to rather NOT use this option, because : Every request to that cache-file throws on the php engine and occupies one PHP userslot for a very short time, but on an average shared hosting server, PHP userslots usually are limited. A userslot is occopied while a PHP script is processing. Yet - on the other hand - the script is very very tiny and needs very very short time to process, so probably even if you have extremely many visitors, it will not cause problems ever at all, ever. A normal average website can use this with no problems. This is just for your information.
